Alex,

I'm assuming that you're "externalizing your dependencies" in your Struts
action.  Meaning that you've got set/get methods for things that provide
JavaMail interfaces in your Struts action.  So how are you currently
injecting the JavaMail objects into your Struts action??

Assuming you are doing that, it could be as simple as mocking JavaMail
(using easymock, for example, I don't know if mockobjects itself has
JavaMail mocks) and injecting those to your Struts action in setUp.

If your struts action class hierarchy is "hardwired" to get references to
JavaMail (e.g. through JNDI), then you've shot yourself in the foot.  But
I'm thinking that's not the problem.  I think mocking JavaMail is the part
that's not done for you yet.

Forgive my obscurity around JavaMail.  It's not an API I'm incredibly
familiar with, but the external dependency problem is one I've been dealing
with quite a bit.

The trick of subclassing the object you're testing to override and provide
mock implementations of dependencies may not work with MockStrutsTestCase,
because it's bound to the struts-config file to invoke the execute method.
Seems like there should be some way to override that configuration to point
to the subclass, but I'm not sure how much that would buy you.

Perhaps some code snippet from your action's execute method would help
clarify your problem, or at least allow me/us to provide more concrete
examples of ways around.

Hope some of this helps.

Later,
-Larry

From: emilander [mailto:emilander@...]

Subject: [junit] Testing a Struts Action with a mock back end



I am trying to write some unit tests for a Struts Action that uses 
JavaMail to send a message. It seems to do this I'll need to 

1 - Use a junit extension built for Struts
2 - Use IOC to substitute a mock JavaMail implementation for the 
real thing.

I have found StrutsTestCase (http://strutstestcase.sourceforge.net/) 
as a framework for doing #1, but it does not seem to allow me to do 
#2. I could do #2 without #1 by refactoring into a helper class, but 
that would leave the action untested.

Do anyone have any ideas how to do both #1 and #2?

Thanks
Alex
